newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Renault will not reconsider Belgian plant closure.
newsitem.headline: Renault will not reconsider Belgian plant closure.

text.p: French car maker Renault will not reconsider its decision to close its Belgian plant, Renault chief executive officer Louis Schweitzer told Belgian newspapers in an interview on Thursday.
"As long as the unions stick to the idea that our decision to close the Vilvoorde plant will be reconsidered, we will make no progress," Schweitzer told Belgian daily La Libre Belgique.

"I understand that it is hard to accept the Vilvoorde plant closure, but there are other things in life that are hard to accept...we should face reality and avoid illusions," he told Belgian financial daily De Financieel-Economische Tijd.
Schweitzer said, however, that he regretted the political fallout of the decision.
"If I could do it over, my announcement would explain more completely the reasons for the closure," he said.
Renault's shock announcement on February 27 that it would close down the profitable factory in July with the loss of 3,100 jobs led to street protests and has strained Belgian-French relations.
Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene, in whose constituency the plant is located, has sharply criticized Renault.
Nearly 3,000 job losses have also been announced by Renault in France. Renault said last week it lost 5.25 billion French francs in 1996.
